title: Step invoked by output_from/named_output/provides cannot recognized task variable defined in global statement.
body:
Hi Bo,

I have encountered an error where invoking other step by output_from , named_output , and `provides` will cause the task statement not being able to recognize the global statement. Following error was given 
```
ERROR: [A (A)]: [A]: Failed to execute process
"bash(fr"""touch {_output}\n""", stderr = f'{_output}.stderr',...'{_output}.stdout')\n"
name 'walltime' is not defined
[B]: Exits with 1 pending step (B)
```
when running 
```
sos run test_global.sos B -J 1 -q csg -c csg.yml
```
Where test_global.sos is:

```
[global]
# The output directory for generated files. MUST BE FULL PATH
parameter: cwd = path("./")
# For cluster jobs, number commands to run per job
parameter: job_size = 1
# Wall clock time expected
parameter: walltime = "5h"
# Memory expected
parameter: mem = "16G"
# Number of threads
parameter: numThreads = 8

[A]
output: file = f'{cwd:a}/test_file'
task: trunk_workers = 1, walltime = walltime, mem = mem, cores = numThreads, tags = f'{step_name}_{_output:bn}'
bash: expand= "$[ ]", stderr = f'{_output}.stderr', stdout = f'{_output}.stdout'
    touch $[_output]
[B]
input: output_from("A")
task: trunk_workers = 1, walltime = walltime, mem = mem, cores = numThreads, tags = f'{step_name}_{_output:bn}'
bash: expand= "$[ ]", stderr = f'{_output}.stderr', stdout = f'{_output}.stdout'
    touch $[_input]
```
However, I was under the impression that this mechanism should work fine previously.

The sos version I am using is the latest. And the pbs version is sos-pbs 0.20.8

title: SoS not sending updated workflow
body:
Thanks very much for your help with #1434, but I've noticed a somewhat similar issue. When I'm submitting workflows to a cluster and I subtly update a workflow `task` statement, it is still submitted with the older values. For example I had a step where a few substeps were timing out on the cluster so I changed the step's task statement from `task: walltime='00:30:00', mem='6G', trunk_size=40, trunk_workers=10` to `task: walltime='00:45:00', mem='6G', trunk_size=40, trunk_workers=10` but the update workflow still had the same task id as before and on the cluster still had a walltime of 30 minutes. If I ran `sos purge` on the task and resubmitted, then the walltime would be updated. The full cell would look like this
```
%run call_variants -q yale_hpc_task_spooler -r yale_hpc_task_spooler mem="4GB" cores=1 walltime="12:00:00" nodes=1 -e ignore

[call_variants]
input: output_from("print_reads"), group_by=1
output: f'/home/pgc29/scratch60/helen_mixed_infection/data/vcf/\
{os.path.split(_input[0].resolve())[1].split(".bam")[0]}.vcf.gz'
task: walltime='00:30:00', mem='3G', trunk_size=40, trunk_workers=10, 
    workdir='/home/pgc29/scratch60/helen_mixed_infection/data/vcf'
run: expand=True
    module load BCFtools
    bcftools mpileup {_input} --threads 1 -AI \
    -f /home/pgc29/scratch60/helen_mixed_infection/dataraw/GCF_000195955.2_ASM19595v2_genomic.fna \
    -R /home/pgc29/scratch60/helen_mixed_infection/dataraw/targets_NC_000962.3.tsv.gz \
    -a FMT/AD  -Ou |
    bcftools call -A -m --prior 1e-2 -Ou --ploidy 1 |
    bcftools annotate -x INFO,^FORMAT/GT,^FORMAT/AD -Oz  -o {_output}

title: Workflow on compute node doesn't update hosts.yml
body: I've got my scripts up and running with the new option to submit the workflow to a cluster compute node and it's great. Thanks for all the work on cluster support over the last few months. One slight thing I noticed while I was iterating things to get them working is that my local hosts.yml is copied to `~/.sos/config_{self.alias}.yml` on the cluster. However, if I update my local hosts.yml and then submit a new workflow to the cluster from my local notebook, the cluster `~/.sos/config_{self.alias}.yml` file doesn't get updated. Shouldn't these be kept in sync?

title: Verbosity is not passed to workers correctly under Python 3.8
body:
In python 3.8 on Mac,  [ the default spawn method is changed to spawn](https://bugs.python.org/issue33725) so I am seeing problems with `-v1` not passed to workers.

Fork is faster but this change would ensure the correct passing of global variables under windows, and now on mac.

title: Failure to save results and signatures of completed subtasks when master tasks are killed
body:
For my earlier submission of thousands of substeps (about 20K) as about 1K tasks each having 20 substeps, I got some failures. When I fix my code and resubmit, I see more submitted jobs than expected:

```
INFO: M20_8250b19e9a9b5435 submitted to midway2 with job id 63825899
INFO: M20_7c665000478155e5 submitted to midway2 with job id 63825901
INFO: M20_c2dbff87ce2436c9 submitted to midway2 with job id 63825904
INFO: Waiting for the completion of 50 tasks before submitting 1521 pending ones.
INFO: M20_366084e8befddcbb submitted to midway2 with job id 63825930
INFO: M20_2e099a81d3f2c361 submitted to midway2 with job id 63825932
INFO: M20_612b2a2a35f4d851 submitted to midway2 with job id 63825933
INFO: Waiting for the completion of 50 tasks before submitting 1518 pending ones.
INFO: M20_06aec99666ae8966 submitted to midway2 with job id 63825984
INFO: Waiting for the completion of 50 tasks before submitting 1517 pending ones.
INFO: M20_ee9a017c3c6a6af7 submitted to midway2 with job id 63826018
INFO: Waiting for the completion of 50 tasks before submitting 1516 pending ones.

INFO: Waiting for the completion of 50 tasks before submitting 1516 pending ones.
```

as you can see what happens is that the same failed task will still be resubmitted even though maybe 19/20 of them were successful they will only be skipped when the M20 task is executed. That means they claim the same resource and  stay in the queue. It thus takes lots of time to recover maybe only a handful of failed runs. What I have to do now is to remove all task from `~/.sos` and start with `-s build` in order to skip existing valid output. I think it would make sense to regroup substeps and  generate new tasks to avoid such overhead.

title: .err file appears after a task completes
body: Right now when a task is completed, it absorbs `.err` file into the `.task` file so that the error messages can be embedded (and be retrieved from `sos status`). However, on the cluster system, the `.err` files are written some time after the jobs are completed, so the task file can contain partial `.err` file.

title: Fate of running tasks when the master process is killed.
body:
Simple workflow

```
task:
import time
time.sleep(10)
```
Run it
```
sos run test
```
and kill it after the task is completed, the task will be showing `running` until after 1 minutes when it is claimed to be `aborted`. When the workflow is executed again before the task is shown to be `aborted`, it will say the task is `already running` but cannot do anything to make sure it completes properly.

title: Execution of global section of task can fail on remote host

```

  print(something)

[default]
a()
```
is ok, but
```

title: target attributes in signature
body:
Current our runtime signature does not save target variables so the restored output target does not have any variable and can cause trouble. It is however a bit difficult to save signature with targets though because there are currently arbitrary pickle-able targets in an unordered fashion so it can be difficult to save signature if the variables are large and validating variables can be troublesome. ... and I am not even sure if variables need to be compared because these information can be considered as mutable/volatile.

Anyway, this needs to be done with more contents in targets.

title: sos purge remote tasks
body:
It seems that

```
sos purge -q remote
```
only purges task files on remote hosts but in reality it seems necessary to remove local copies as well. However, technically speaking, the command asks to purge tasks on remote host and it is possible to use the local task files to submit to another remote host.

title: Missing stderr from failed remote task
body:
In some cases the remote task returns something like

```
Task 1200196153a684f4 exits with code 1
```
with missing actual `stderr`.

This should be fixed because it makes it really difficult to check what went wrong. Basically users have to log on to the remote host and re-execute the task with command `sos execute task_id`.


```

title: sos tasks across different queues on the same system.
body:
It is a common practice, at least for my applications, that I create two queues for clusters, one for the headnode for small tasks such as file synchronization, and one for real jobs submitted to the cluster.

The problem is that the `.sos/tasks` folders are shared by the two queues and the status of the tasks are queued together. So when

1. The cluster is running a bunch of jobs using the PBS queue
2. I submit a few tasks to be executed on the headnode

The headnode jobs will not be run because the number of running jobs exceeds the number of allowed running jobs for the headnode queue, although the tasks are actually running for the PBS queue.

title: Option shared of steps with substeps
body:
Option shared returns step variables to the master process but it is entirely sure what happens to steps with substeps. 

Basically, option `shared` evaluates and returns variables after the completion of a step. However,

1. SoS only makes sure `step_output` exists and contains the collection of substep output (`_output`).
2. For other variables, 
  2.a: if `concurrent=True`, the substeps are executed in separate processes and currently does not return any variable.
  2.b: if `concurrent=False`, the substeps are executed sequentially so the variable is the "end result" after all substeps. That is to say, if each substeps returns a different value, only the last value is caught.

So in theory the `shared` variable will have to be substep-specific, that is to say, 

```
[1: shared='a']
input:  for_each={'b': range(2)}
a = b
```
should return `a=[0, 1]` for value `b=0` and `b=1` for different substeps, and
```
[1: shared='a']
a = 1
```
should in theory returns `a=[1]` (or `[{'a': 1}]`) to reflect the fact that there is one substep, but this is not how this option works now.

As pointed out in #968, there is also a problem when changing the target to using file target. But maybe fixing this problem will lead to fix of that one, so let's focus on this one for now and I'll try reproducing the file target version bug after this one is addressed to.

title: `dryrun` get caught in infinite loop
body:
I've noticed this issue for a while but did not find a motivation to fix it until today: I've got asked by someone to provide pure scripts from my workflow, so I did a `dryrun`. But I got caught in an infinite loop. To reproduce, 

```
a=file_target('1.txt')

[out: provides=a]
output: a
run: expand = True
  touch {a}

[1]
depends: a
print('hi')
```

then `sos dryrun test.sos`. 

Not sure if this behavior is easy to fix ...

title: Identical tasks cause clashes
body:
Here is a MWE:

```
[1]
input: '1.txt', '1.txt', group_by = 1, concurrent = True
output: [x + '.out' for x in _input]
bash: expand = True
  touch {_output}
```

So there are two tasks involved and they are identical -- meaning that they are exactly the same in all aspects. The above workflow ends in an infinite loop. 

A related point is, that is there any way we can obtain only the unique tasks before sending to build DAG and run?

title: Invalid file_target created from functions in pathlib.Path
body:
```
>>> from sos.runtime import file_target
>>> a = file_target('test.txt')
>>> a._md5
>>> b = a.with_suffix('.sos')
>>> b
file_target('test.sos')
>>> b._md5
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
AttributeError: 'file_target' object has no attribute '_md5'
```
The reason for this is that `a.with_suffix('.sos')` is called from the base class, which creates a `pathlib.Path`, but not the `_md5` attribute from `file_target`. I do not quite understand why this happens but we will need to fix it.

body:
Here is the MWE:
```
[1]

print(_input)
```
and error message:

```
ERROR: Failed to regenerate or resolve _2.txt requested by .
```

I believe this is introduced due to the use of `libpath` because this workflow used to work for me. In my actual case the input were interpreted to `Undetermined('')` rather than `file_target()`, but I cannot reproduce that behavior with a MWE.

title: Remove expand option from action after parsing
body:
This is usually not a problem but suppose the action does not accept option `expand`, having `expand` in the list can cause problem. For example,

```
len: expand='${ }'
    something ${1}
```
would fail because `len` does not take keyword parameter `expand`.

title: Trouble with input[0]
body:
Currently variables `input`, `_input`, etc are of type `sos_targets`, which contains a list of strings (filenames) and other targets. We have special rules to format `sos_targets` so that

1. It treats string as filename.
2. It formats each item and join the results.

This works ok for `f"{input}"` but a serious problem is with `f"{input[0]}"` because `input[0]` can be a normal string so `${input[0]:n}` would not work. If we have to make `input[0]` work, we will have to change `input[0] to `FileTarget` type. The problem is that this type will then be everywhere in sos source code and in sos scripts such as `action: input=output[0]` so that actions needs to handle this type as well. 

So a lot of work to fix a seeming easy use case.

title: Type trait conflict with sos action
body:
Currently, variables with type trait
```
aaa: list = [40]
```
would be considered as an action `aaa` with option `list = [40]`. This needs to be resolved or we have to discourage the use of type trait in SoS.

title: Input parameter of actions.
body:
The input parameter of actions actually serves two purposes now:

1. for script running actions, the content of the input will be prepended to the script.
2. if both `input` and `output` exist, sos will try to create a task level signature to skip the action.

I did not realize this problem when we added feature 1. It is a bad idea to let one parameter server two purposes.... for example, if a user wants to create step signature with some arbitrary `input`, then the script will be broken.

title: Monitor of task failed
body:
I've got errors in my jobs that I cannot reproduce with MWE:

```
f52d9658a018085e6a00abc693e7b701.err:
=====================================
2017-10-23 23:56:11,290: INFO: f52d9658a018085e6a00abc693e7b701 ``started``
2017-10-24 00:07:12,680: DEBUG: Monitor of f52d9658a018085e6a00abc693e7b701 failed with message psutil.NoSuchProcess process no longer exists (pid=11451)

f52d9658a018085e6a00abc693e7b701.out:
=====================================
```

Basically each of these task calls a variant of [this script](https://github.com/knmkr/lift-over-vcf) which runs one `liftover` for every variant; each `liftover` will result in a PID. I run this for all chroms in parallel. After a few minutes the jobs started, they all failed like this:

```
WARNING: Result for f52d9658a018085e6a00abc693e7b701 is not received
ERROR: 23 jobs aborted
```
But in fact the actual python process of `vcf-liftover` still seems to be running and the result files are still constantly updated. I'll wait until it finishes to check the outcome. Maybe the task PID can change for python scripts involving `subprocess.Popen`?

title: No effective way to stop a lengthy calculation.
body:
Not sure how Jupyter solves this problem but in SoS, if I accidentally evaluate a large matrix, there is no easy way to stop it. Kernel->interrupt will send ctr-C to the subkernel but the Jupyter frontend still displays `*` (busy) and will not accept new inputs.

If `Ctrl-C` has successfully stops the calculation of the underlying kernel, it is a bug in Jupyter or SoS to not able to resume with other commands.

title: -W (no wait) test fail for no obvious reason.
body:
As show in [this travis test](https://travis-ci.org/vatlab/SoS/jobs/287925981), the `test_task.py TestTask.testKillAndPurge` test failed because `sos` command hang after the jobs are submitted. I cannot reproduce this problem on mac, on linux, even on a [TravisCI virtual machine](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/21053657/how-to-run-travis-ci-locally). My suspicion is that the travis server has perhaps only 2 cores so the extra task management thread somehow stopped the execution of a worker.

I am disabling this test for now but I will keep this ticket open and check it when we touch this part of code later.

title: Order of %preview and %run
body:
`%preview` works in

```
%preview -n abc.txt -c ~/docker.yml -r docker
%run -r docker -c ~/docker.yml
sh:
   echo abc > abc.txt
```
but not in 

```
%run -r docker -c ~/docker.yml
%preview -n abc.txt -c ~/docker.yml -r docker
sh:
   echo abc > abc.txt
```

because `%run` execute the rest of the cell as sos script... We should at least warn users about this.

title: Notebook workflow with non-ascii characters
body: Right now we use `btoa` to convert workflow collected from frontend to ascii and pass it to the backend with magic `%frontend`. However, this function will fail if the workflow contains non-ascii characters. We should try to pass the workflow in another method.

title: Restrict `report` only to current cell
body:
Since we are on scope discussions tonight let me bring this up too. Currently:

```
----------code cell----------
[step_1]
report: output=...
<markdown codes>

---------markdown cell--------
<markdown codes>
----------------------------------
```

then the 2nd cell's contents will go into the report section. This is bad because that cell is meant to be some narrative only visiable to myself, and a way to organize notebook contents. Should we restrict report only to current cell?

title: Depends on dynamically generated targets.
body:
Not necessarily dynamic, just some target that cannot be determined by static analysis. For example

```
[10]
input: 'a.txt'
output: "${_input}.bak"
sh:
    cp ${_input} ${_output}

[20]
depends: "a.txt.bak"
sh:
    ls ${_depends}

```

fails because the output of step 10 is undetermined because of difficulties in identifying `_input`. Then step 20 cannot run because of its dependency on the output. Instead of raising an error, the correct behavior would be leaving the decision of missing targets after step 10 is completed.

title: Writing matrix to by using feather in Julia
body: The problem here is that: When we want to transfer a `matrix` from `Julia` to `Python`, we need to convert the `matrix` to `dataframe` first, and then save it by using `feather`. However, when it saves a `dataframe`, we can see that the first row is `1 │ 4294967297 │ 4294967297`, which should not be the case. I'm not sure if it is the bug of the package or the problem or myself... Maybe we should think another way to do it? However, it will also happen for `dataframe` in `Julia`.

title: Multiple %run magics
body:
```
%run --par 1
%run --par 2
%run --par 3
```
only the first one is executed (if I observed correctly).

title: for_each support zip
body:
```
for_each={'ID,NID': zip(IDs, NIDs)}
```
returns an error. We should support iterator like `zip` in `for_each`.

title: Problem with automatic preview
body:
Currently, for 

```
a = func(b)
```

we execute
```
a=func(b)
```
then immediately
```
%preview a
```

However, if `a=func(b)` fails, `%preview a` might be previewing the old value of `a`, and the error message from `a=func(b)` would be covered by `%preview a`.

title: ! command does not do shell expansion
body:
After changing to `pexpect` for `!` magic,

```

```
no longer works, because `pexpect` does not perform shell expansion so `ls` does not know what `~` is.

title: Connection between two remote steps.
body:
```
[step_10]
input: remote('10.in')
output: remote('10.out')

[step_20]
input: remote('10.out')
output: remote('20.out')
```
would fail to execute because `remote('10.txt')` is considered exist locally (for signature considerations) so `step_20` would be executed in parallel to `step_10`. 

For a proper fix, we would have to actually check if `remote()` exists, or execute any step with `remote()` input after other steps.

title: Behavior when shared and path_map disagree with each other
body:
Perhaps it has been correctly handled but I am wondering the behavior of `shared` used in combination with `path_map`.

For example, if `host_A` has

```
paths:
    home: /shared/user 
shared:
    A: /shared
```

and `host_B` has

```
paths:
   home: /home/user
shared:
   A: /scratch/shared
```

So if we following `shared`, if we push `/shared/user/something` to `host_B`, the file would not be copied because is shared, and the destination file would be `/scratch/shared/user/something`.

However, if we follow `paths`, `/shared/user/something` should be mapped to `/home/user/something`. 

It is not entirely clear which map should be used, although `path_map` should override `shared`. Then it seems that the `rsync` command should be changed to a `rsync` command on the remote server from `/scratch/shared/user/something` to `/home/user/something`.

title: Difference of valid variable names between Matlab and Python
body: In Matlab, the variable names beginning with underline(_) are not the valid variable. However, it is valid in Python. So it might cause some problems. Although it is a tiny problem, I think we should specify that in the documentation.

title: Remove updated content in .err and .out files
body:
Currently if we execute a task repeatedly, all output and error messages will be appended to existing `.out` and `.err` files. Consequently, it is difficult to tell which output/error belong to the most recent execution.

We should either remove existing `.err` and `.out` file with each new execution, or separate the messages with something like `... started...`. I suppose the first solution is easier.

title: Confusing on parameter, definition, and global variable.
body:
Suppose in notebook, we have

```
fname = 'a.txt'
```
already defined, then

```
%run --fname b.txt

input: fname
```
would actually take `a.txt` because `fname` is not defined as parameter, and a value already exists. We should either

1. stop using global variables ( #690 ) so that `fname` is undefined when it is not defined in `parameter`.
2. check for unused variable and notify user that `--fname b.txt` is not used because `fname` is not defined in `parameter`.

title: Method and frequency of checking job status.
body:
Checking status of a job is not very easy, basically we need to check if a status file has been updated in the past 5 seconds or so for running jobs, and check the time stamp of task, result, and status files in other cases. A bigger problem is how frequently we should check the status of jobs.

We are checking the status of a job every 2 seconds at the beginning, and at about 30 seconds for long jobs. This does not sound like much but if we have 100 jobs on the cluster,, we are firing 3000 login request to the cluster to check the status of these jobs. This is not acceptable.

Not sure how we can address this problem.

title: to_host does not work remotely.
body:
For example

```
task:  on_host='machine', path_map='/home/user:/Users/user', to_host=input
sh:
   touch ${to_host(output)} 
```

Option `to_host=input` works because its how to expand `input` to full path name and convert to dest name. However, `to_host` function is executed on the remote machine and does not know how to expand `output` to full path name (relative to local machine), so the path translation would fail.

The solution I think is to 
1. pass all variables `input`, `output` etc as full path name to remote machine (so that the translation can be done). ...
2. perform `to_host` calculation locally

title: remote job does not abort when local sos job interrupted by keyboard
body: Right now the local job just waits for the remote job to complete. When the local job is killed (e.g. keyboard interrupted), the remote job would keep running. There should be some way to manage remote process.

%cell code collapsed=False kernel=sos
a=1

b<-100
b

%cell code collapsed=True

```

title: A skip magic?
body:
Say a cell of a notebook needs hours to execute and does not need to be executed each time. It would make sense to use magic 

```
%skip
```

to skip the cell. We can also make it more flexible by something like

```
%skip --if ${os.path.isfile('result.txt'}
```

of course the syntax could be made cleaner.

title: Control number of jobs in case of nested workflow.
body:
Right now `sos_run` observes `-j` option independent of the master process. So running a subworkflow in multi-processing mode essentially does

```
J1
J2
J3 --> sos_run --> J5, J6, J7, J8
J4 
```

It should in theory have a process pool to which master and nested workflows send jobs to.

title: automatic variable sharing with random jump.
body:
Currently automatic variable sharing is implemented by following the kernel jump. However, there are cases where kernel jump are random which makes automatic variable sharing difficult. For example, 

If there are existing cells with type python and sos,

```
cell python
a= 1
```

when we jump to the following cell, sos does not know that we are jumping out of python so `a` is not updated...

```
cell sos
a
```

title: Front-end failed when kernel is not ready.
body:
I notice that `IPython.kernel.execute` might not already be ready when we execute 
[this line](https://github.com/vatlab/SOS/blob/master/sos/jupyter/kernel.js#L68), which cause the whole frontend to fail.

To reproduce:

1. Start jupyter notebook
2. Create a notebook with SoS kernel
3. From File-> New -> SoS, start a new notebook

In this case the frontend is called but the kernel is not yet ready. The consequence is that the frontend code is not executed, `sos_comm` is not ready, so the frontend cannot receive message from the kernel.

The solution,

1. There is a kernel ready event, perhaps we can do kernel related work in that event.
2. We can move the `sos_comm` registration code before any kernel related code so that comm will always be open. Then, we can perform kernel related work when `sos_comm` receives its first message and the kernel is not configured (e.g. no attribute `orig_execute`.

title: Name conflict of sos actions and targets.
body:
Perhaps I am a bit paranoid but I am concerned that, with increasing capacity of sos, there would be increasing potential of name conflict. In the worst case a perfect-running workflow might not work because of added symbols. 

For example, a user might define

```
parameter: perl = '/path/to/perl'

run:
    ${perl} 

```

which does not work, because, unlike in normal python a statement would be executed only once (so `perl` will override system `perl`), statements in sos could be executed multiple times (e.g. `perl` be re-imported) that overrides user values.

There are potentially two solutions:

1. Alias system symbols so that 

    ```
    run:
      script
    ```
    is actually

    ```
    __sos_run('''script''')
    ```

    The problem is that we currently allow actions to be called like regular functions, so consequently there is no way to pick out actions in a normal Python statement and alias it.

    Targets are easier to aliasa because they are used in fixed locations, but can still be a hassle to implement it.

2. Import SoS symbols only once and allows users to update sos symbols. It is a bit tricky to implement but can be done. It also has a advantage (or disadvantage) that users can redefine system actiosn to change the way sos behave. 

    ```
    def run ...
   ```

    We can sort of warn users of such problems by scanning the sos dictionary that test the type of known actions and targets, and warn users if they are not of type action and/or target.

title: Kill of waiting sos process kills the sos process in action.
body:
For some reason that I do not yet understand.
1. Start sos, working on something (`A`)
2. Start another sos command (`B`) working on the same workflow
3. `B` shows "waiting for another process" when it cannot get the lock
4. `Ctrl-C` to kill `B`, but `A` is also killed.

title: Repeated execution of auxiliary steps.
body:
For example

```
[A: provides=('fileA.txt', 'fileB.txt')]
sh:
  touch fileA.txt
  touch fileB.txt

[1]
depends: 'fileA.txt'

[2]
depends: 'fileB.txt'
```

SoS will create two versions of `A`, one providing `fileA.txt` and one providing `fileB.txt`. This is incorrect and can sometimes cause errors. However, this behavior is needed for cases such as

```
[A: provides='{file}.txt']
sh:
  touch ${file}.txt

[1]
depends: 'fileA.txt'

[2]
depends: 'fileB.txt'
```

because step `A` needs to be customized for different output. It seems that we need to somehow differentiate between these two cases.

title: sos run using variable as input
body:
For script

```
[A_10: shared='res']

[A_20]
input: res

[A_21]
input: res
```

because `res` is not recognizable during initial DAG building, inputs of `A_20` and `A_21` are considered `Undetermind`, and therefore `A_21` would follow `A_20`, rather than `A_10`. Some more clever DAG building is required here.

title: Namespace issue with %include
body:
Say in `included.sos` there are variables and steps

```
parameter: a = 1

[do_something]
'${a}'

```

and in master.sos we have

```
%include included
```

The workflows and variables are referred to as

```
included.a
included.do_something
```

However `included.do_something` would fail because it looks for `a` but only `included.a` is available. The workflow running code should be made aware of how to execute workflow `included.do_something` (namely passing `included.a` as `a` to the step).

Note that

```
%from included include *
```

does not suffer from this problem because both `a` and `do_something` are directly available in the namespace.

title: sos run -r (run mode) does not work with auxiliary steps.
body: Auxiliary steps are determined in prepare stage during the creation of DAG. It is therefore difficult to skip the prepare step if there are auxiliary steps. It is possible to look up steps during execution but it does not seem to worth the trouble to do it.
